title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
text:
Status: completed
I finalized the design and documentation of a modular research folder structure intended for projects that grow over time, not just projects that end with a paper.
The guiding principle is straightforward:
separate thinking, data, code, and evidence early and deliberately.

title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
text:
Structure overview
The system is organized into three tiers, each mapped to a realistic research workload.

Basic
For literature-driven work and small academic projects.


Standard
For master-level research and publication-oriented analysis.


Advanced
For doctoral and multi-year research with experiment tracking and reproducibility requirements.

title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
text:
Design rationale
The emphasis is not on folder count, but on decision clarity.

Raw data remains immutable

Manuscripts are modular rather than monolithic

Code is reproducible, not exploratory residue

Experiments leave a traceable record

A well-designed structure is not administrative overhead.
It is cognitive infrastructure.

title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
text:
Outcome
This setup reduces friction when switching between projects, revisiting old analyses, preparing manuscripts or proposals, and scaling collaboration or solo work.
No tooling is enforced.
LaTeX, JabRef, Git, Python, and R integrate naturally, but nothing is mandatory.
Outcome: less time managing artifacts, more time spent on actual research.

title: Designing a Research Folder Structure That Scales
text:
Next step
Using this structure as the backbone for long-horizon computational biology projects.

title: Notes on Phenotypic Screening and System-Level Drug Discovery
text:
Context: This essay emerged from ongoing reading and synthesis around phenotypic screening, polypharmacology, and systems-level failure modes in drug discovery. The initial trigger was revisiting historical drug examples alongside recent critiques of screening paradigms.
Process Notes:

Compared classical phenotypic discoveries (aspirin, metformin, sirolimus) with contemporary target-first workflows.
Integrated perspectives from systems biology, cancer resistance literature, and network pharmacology.
Identified recurring patterns where translational failure reflects model mismatch rather than technical insufficiency.

Open Questions:

How can network-level readouts be standardized without collapsing back into reductionism?
What experimental designs best support causal inference in phenotypic–omics integration?
Where should industry draw the line between exploratory interrogation and pipeline efficiency?

Next Steps:

Explore concrete case studies combining phenotypic screens with single-cell omics.
Examine decision criteria used internally by industry teams when choosing discovery paradigms.

This entry documents the reasoning process behind a longer conceptual essay, rather than presenting a finalized position.
